results.title: Battle Royale Over Rightful Heir to Israeli Self-Defense Discipline
results.abstract: Krav Maga, which extols eye gouging and groin kicking, is a mainstay of military training and increasingly popular with civilians. Now, its founder’s disciples are sparring over who is the real grandmaster.

multimedia.caption: Haim Gidon, left, a claimant to the Krav Maga grandmaster title, at the beach in his hometown, Netanya, Israel. “Even with eye gouging, you have to know how,” he said. “You have to bring your thumb all the way in.”

results.title: Kazakhstan Prizes Its Cowboys, but Few Want to Saddle Up for Harsh Life
results.abstract: Kazakh cowboys, while proud of providing their rapidly modernizing nation with a link to its nomadic past, rarely want their children to follow them onto the frigid steppes.

multimedia.caption: Erlan Kozhakov, 63, a herder on the sandy scrub land between Kazakhstan’s biggest city and the Chinese border.

results.title: Some Afghan Children Find an Alternative to Jail — for Now
results.abstract: Orphanages for Afghan children of jailed mothers meet part of the need, but funding cuts threaten their future and many others stay in prison.

multimedia.caption: Playtime at the Children’s Support Center in Kabul, an orphanage-like facility for children whose mothers are in prison, and that is in danger of losing its funding.

results.title: The BBC in Pidgin? People Like It Well-Well
results.abstract: The British broadcaster, once a bastion of “received pronunciation,” has learned that if it wants to reach new audiences, it needs to try new approaches.

multimedia.caption: An article on the BBC website telling the story of a Tinder date gone wrong, written in West African pidgin English.

results.title: City of the Future? Humans, Not Technology, Are the Challenge in Toronto
results.abstract: Plans by a Google sibling for a development where robots collect trash and heated paths melt snow have generated excitement. But its data-collection sensors have spurred privacy concerns.

results.title: Turkey Completes Deal to Buy Antimissile System From Russia
results.abstract: The deal would make Turkey the first member of NATO to own Russia’s most advanced air defense system, and it has raised concerns among Turkey’s NATO allies.

multimedia.caption: Turkish news media reported on Friday that Turkey would purchase four S-400 units from Russia at a cost of $2.5 billion.
